Module Simulator
Package kin.execmodels

Class ManipulatorModel

java.lang.Object
kin.execmodels.ManipulatorModel
All Implemented Interfaces:
Manipulator
Direct Known Subclasses:
Lift, Lift2, ManipulatorWith3DOFGripper, Tripod
public abstract class ManipulatorModel
extends java.lang.Object
implements Manipulator
An abstract class for different manipulators. It both provides the setup for the simulation as well as the developer access according to Manipulator.

    Inverse-Kinematics-Method: 1: preferred, 2: closed solution, 3: downhill optimization, 4: Jacobian matrix approach

      Pass the static body model instance in order to create a dynamic model and to create maps of servos and linear motors.
      Parameters:
      bodyModel - the body (i.e. root) component
      joints - array of joints each an array of 2 with [0]: type (e.g. Joint.TYPE_SERVO) and [1]: servo or motor ID
      targetComponentModel - the model component that defines the target position

    • privateMoveWristTo

      protected abstract ManipulatorResult privateMoveWristTo​(double x, double y, double z, double gripperAngXY, double gripperAngXZ, double gripperAngYZ, int speedIndicator, double absoluteSpeed, double relativeSpeed)

      Inner manipulator method, to perform direct, non-linear wrist movement. This method must not be called by the application developer, call moveWristTo(double, double, double,double,double,double,int,double,double) instead.

      The movement follows the interpolation of the involved servos and motors from start to target angles or lengths. This means, the result trajectory of the wrist is not linear.

      The movement is initiated, but the command immediately returns, i.e. the movement is performed from now.
      Parameters:
      x - local coordinate x (cm)
      y - local coordinate y (cm)
      z - local coordinate z (cm)
      gripperAngXY - angle of the gripper segment in the x-y plane (yaw orientation, applied last); may be NaN, if the gripper angle should not change
      gripperAngXZ - angle of the gripper segment in the x-z plane (gripper angle to horizon, applied second); may be NaN, if the gripper angle should not change
      gripperAngYZ - angle of the gripper segment in the y-z plane (gripper axis-rotation, applied first); may be NaN, if the gripper angle should not change
      speedIndicator - speed indicator,
      • 0: all motors with default speed
      • 1: all motors should terminate at the same time, whereas the motor that makes the largest move (i.e. those that moves quickest) should run with a relative speed to the maximum (see parameter relativeSpeed)
      • 2: all motors should terminate at the same time, where as the gripper moves with predefined speed (see parameter absoluteSpeed); limit the given speed by the maximum speed resulting by motor limits. Note: the parameter relativeSpeed is also used here to compute the minimum moving time for the gripper servos.
      absoluteSpeed - if speedIndicator==2 absolute gripper speed in cm/s
      relativeSpeed - if speedIndicator==1 relative speed to the maximum for the motor with longest runtime, also used if speedIndicator==2 to define the speed of the gripper servos
      Returns:
      result of the command

    • moveWristTo

      public ManipulatorResult moveWristTo​(double x, double y, double z, double gripperAngXY, double gripperAngXZ, double gripperAngYZ, int speedIndicator, double absoluteSpeed, double relativeSpeed)
      Description copied from interface: Manipulator

      Move the wrist to a given position. The wrist is the nearest component to the gripper.

      The movement follows the interpolation of the involved servos from start to target angle. This means, the result trajectory of the wrist is not linear.

      The movement is initiated, but the command immediately returns, i.e. the movement is performed from now.
      Specified by:
      moveWristTo in interface Manipulator
      Parameters:
      x - local coordinate x (cm)
      y - local coordinate y (cm)
      z - local coordinate z (cm)
      gripperAngXY - angle of the gripper segment in the x-y plane (yaw orientation, applied last); may be NaN, if the gripper angle should not change
      gripperAngXZ - angle of the gripper segment in the x-z plane (gripper angle to horizon, applied second); may be NaN, if the gripper angle should not change
      gripperAngYZ - angle of the gripper segment in the y-z plane (gripper axis-rotation, applied first); may be NaN, if the gripper angle should not change
      speedIndicator - speed indicator,
      • 0: all motors with default speed
      • 1: all motors should terminate at the same time, whereas the motor that makes the largest move (i.e. those that moves quickest) should run with a relative speed to the maximum (see parameter relativeSpeed)
      • 2: all motors should terminate at the same time, where as the gripper moves with predefined speed (see parameter absoluteSpeed); limit the given speed by the maximum speed resulting by motor limits. Note: the parameter relativeSpeed is also used here to compute the minimum moving time for the gripper servos.
      absoluteSpeed - if speedIndicator==2 absolute gripper speed in cm/s
      relativeSpeed - if speedIndicator==1 relative speed to the maximum for the motor with longest runtime, also used if speedIndicator==2 to define the speed of the gripper servos
      Returns:
      result of the command

    • moveWristLinearTo

      public ManipulatorResult moveWristLinearTo​(double x, double y, double z, double gripperAngXY, double gripperAngXZ, double gripperAngYZ, double relativeSpeed, double segmentLength)
      Description copied from interface: Manipulator

      Move the wrist to a given position. The wrist is the nearest component to the gripper.

      Concerning motor speed: the speed is computed according the maximum motor speed. The calles provides a relatitv speed. If e.g. the relativ speed is 0.5, the servo that makes the largest move (i.e. must move quickest) is powered with 50% of the maximum speed.

      The movement of the wrist is nearly linear. For this, the linear connection from current to target position is segmented and each segment is moved by Manipulator.moveWristTo(double, double, double,double,double,double,int,double,double). Obviously, this is only an approximation of linear movement as inside the segments, the wrist is moved by interpolating servo angles and motor distances. i.e. not linear concerning wrist position.

      The movement is initiated, but the command immediately returns, i.e. the movement is performed from now.
      Specified by:
      moveWristLinearTo in interface Manipulator
      Parameters:
      x - local coordinate x (cm)
      y - local coordinate y (cm)
      z - local coordinate z (cm)
      gripperAngXY - angle of the gripper segment in the x-y plane (yaw orientation, applied last); may be NaN, if the gripper angle should not change
      gripperAngXZ - angle of the gripper segment in the x-z plane (gripper angle to horizon, applied second); may be NaN, if the gripper angle should not change
      gripperAngYZ - angle of the gripper segment in the y-z plane (gripper axis-rotation, applied first); may be NaN, if the gripper angle should not change
      relativeSpeed - relative speed to the maximum for the motor that makes the largest move (i.e. those that moves quickest)
      segmentLength - distance in cm that is moved by interpolating servo angles and motor distances, i.e. not linear concerning wrist position.
      Returns:
      result of the command

    • moveWristLinearToWithConstantSpeed

      public ManipulatorResult moveWristLinearToWithConstantSpeed​(double x, double y, double z, double gripperAngXY, double gripperAngXZ, double gripperAngYZ, double absoluteSpeed, double relativeSpeed, double segmentLength)
      Description copied from interface: Manipulator

      Move the wrist to a given position. The wrist is the nearest component to the gripper.

      Concerning motor speed: the called defines an absolute gripper speed in cm/s. This methods tries to power all involved motors to hold this speed. Only, if the respective motor speeds would be higher than the maximum motor speed, a lower gripper speed results.

      The movement of the wrist is nearly linear. For this, the linear connection from current to target position is segmented and each segment is moved by Manipulator.moveWristTo(double, double, double,double,double,double,int,double,double). Obviously, this is only an approximation of linear movement as inside the segments, the wrist is moved by interpolating servo angles and motor distances. i.e. not linear concerning wrist position.

      The movement is initiated, but the command immediately returns, i.e. the movement is performed from now.
      Specified by:
      moveWristLinearToWithConstantSpeed in interface Manipulator
      Parameters:
      x - local coordinate x (cm)
      y - local coordinate y (cm)
      z - local coordinate z (cm)
      gripperAngXY - angle of the gripper segment in the x-y plane (yaw orientation, applied last); may be NaN, if the gripper angle should not change
      gripperAngXZ - angle of the gripper segment in the x-z plane (gripper angle to horizon, applied second); may be NaN, if the gripper angle should not change
      gripperAngYZ - angle of the gripper segment in the y-z plane (gripper axis-rotation, applied first); may be NaN, if the gripper angle should not change
      absoluteSpeed - absolute gripper speed in cm/s, may be lower in reality, if the desired speed would exceed the respective motor speeds
      relativeSpeed - relative gripper servo speeds (in relation to their maximum) that the gripper servos should run at the maximum
      segmentLength - distance in cm that is moved by interpolating servo angles and motor distances, i.e. not linear concerning wrist position.
      Returns:
      result of the command

    • lastManipulatorResult

      public ManipulatorResult lastManipulatorResult()
      Description copied from interface: Manipulator
      Get the last ManipulatorResult. This is a result of, e.g. calling Manipulator.moveWristTo(double, double, double,double,double,double,int,double,double). In contast to the respective return values, this method may also return a result that occured in background, after calling the movement method.
      Specified by:
      lastManipulatorResult in interface Manipulator
      Returns:
      result of last movement command

    • isCurrentlyMoving

      public boolean isCurrentlyMoving()
      Description copied from interface: Manipulator
      Is the manipulator (including gripper) currently moving? Note: This method is not suitable to check, if a complex movement is still ongoing, as these may occasionally stop (e.g. when intermediate computations take too long). Use Manipulator.ongoingMovement() for this.
      Specified by:
      isCurrentlyMoving in interface Manipulator
      Returns:
      is moving

    • waitCurrentMovementCompleted

      public void waitCurrentMovementCompleted()
      Description copied from interface: Manipulator
      Wait until all movement (including gripper) has been completed. Note: This method is not suitable to wait until a complex movement is still ongoing, as these may occasionally stop (e.g. when intermediate computations take too long). Use Manipulator.waitOngoingMovementCompleted() for this.
      Specified by:
      waitCurrentMovementCompleted in interface Manipulator

    • intermediateTargetNearlyReached

      public boolean intermediateTargetNearlyReached()
      Description copied from interface: Manipulator
      Is the manipulator (including gripper) nearly at target? Nearly means, the target will be reached in less than 0.8 seconds. This may not mean that a complex movement has nearly finished, but only the respective servos and motors nearly reached their (intermediate) targets.
      Specified by:
      intermediateTargetNearlyReached in interface Manipulator
      Returns:
      target nearly reached?

    • waitIntermediateTargetNearlyReached

      public void waitIntermediateTargetNearlyReached()
      Description copied from interface: Manipulator
      Wait until movement (including gripper) nearly reached the target? Nearly means, the target will be reached in less than 0.8 seconds. This may not mean that a complex movement has nearly finished, but only the respective servos and motors nearly reached their (intermediate) targets.
      Specified by:
      waitIntermediateTargetNearlyReached in interface Manipulator
